lesson.title: Intro to Penetration Testing & Red Team Operations
lesson.summary: Brief introduction and foundational knowledge around penetration testing and red teaming.

atoms.title: Meet Your Instructor Heading
atoms.text: ## Hello!

atoms.title: ND350 C2 L0 A00 Meet Your Instructor
Prerequisites Heading
atoms.text: ## Course Prerequisites

atoms.title: ND350 C2 L0 A01 Prerequisites
Prerequisites Summary
atoms.text: # Knowledge * OS Agnostic (Linux / Windows req'd) * CMD shell experience * Networking fundamentals * Background with IT support in some capacity * Some knowledge of vulnerability management * Basic understanding of client-server architecture and secure configurations. * IP Addressing and Sockets, DHCP, DNS, ARP and Access Control Lists (ACL) * Familiar with Log files (Operating System, application, firewall logs) and how to use effectively Use basic cloud technologies to deploy a web server, database, DNS; familiarity with virtual machines, containerization. * Bonus: Experience with incident response # Computer Requirement: * For Access to cloud environment: Any computer with decent internet connection and a web browser. 1 Core CPU, 3GB RAM # Optional Equipment that you may want to have: * **IF you wish to build out your lab environment locally**, then your computer will require the following specs: 2 Core CPU, 8GB RAM (12-16 is even better!), Solid State Hard Drive * **IF you plan to conduct a USB drop Attack:** Rubber ducky from Hack5 * **IF you plan to conduct wireless hacking**, you will need a wireless adapter. The recommended adapter is Alfa AWUSO36NH

atoms.title: Course Outline Heading
atoms.text: ## Welcome to Pen Testing and Red Teaming

atoms.title: ND350 C2 L0 A02 Course Outline
Summary
atoms.text:
### What You Will Learn By The End of This Course
1. Introduction to Reconnaissance - learn about what is reconnaissance and the various ways we collect preliminary information.
2. Scanning & Research - Diving deeper to understand how to use the preliminary information gathered in reconnaissance 
3. Gaining Access - Implement various techniques to penetrate areas of interest. 
4. Maintaining Access - Once you are in the system you want to make sure you can get back in for future needs. 
5. Cover Tracks & Reporting - Implement ways to not be noticed by anyone through gaining or maintaining access. Finally collecting all the information you found so that you have a comprehensive report as a final deliverable.

atoms.title: Course Outline Image
atoms.caption: Course Agenda

concepts.title: Intro to Penetration Testing & Red Teaming

atoms.title: Intro to Penetration Testing & Red Teaming Heading
atoms.text: ## What is Penetration Testing & Red Teaming

atoms.title: ND350 C2 L0 A03 Intro To Penetration Testing & Red Team Ops
Intro to Penetration Testing & Red Teaming Summary
atoms.text:
## Summary

* **Ethical Hacker - **A penetration tester that test only with the explicit permission from the system owner. 
* **Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) - **Responsible for organization Security
* **Chief Information Officer (CIO)** - Responsible for the organization IT Operations

question.prompt: Which of the following roles usually participate in short term Ethical Hacking exercises?
Which of the following teams are usually internal?
Which of the following roles would scan for vulnerabilities but does attempt to exploit those found vulnerabilities?
Which of the following roles usually hack in a production environment?

concepts.title: Penetration Testing & Red Teaming Is Important

atoms.title: Penetration Testing & Red Teaming Is Important Heading
atoms.text: ## The Importance of Penetration Testing & Red Teaming

atoms.title: ND350 C2 L0 A04 Penetration Testing & Red Teaming Is Important
Penetration Testing & Red Teaming Is Important Summary
atoms.text:
## Reasons Why Penetration Testing is Important

### Meeting Compliance
 In the payment card market, it was required to conform to the PCI-DSS Guidelines for the regular annual penetration test. A pen test helps businesses to reduce the actual network threats. NIST the organization that provide guidance for FISMA compliance also suggest some form of pen-testing to be conducted on networks. Best practice suggest a frequency of annual testing.  
### Maintaining Confidentiality 
Pen-test and red team discoveries are confidential between the testing team and the organization as they should be under some form of Non-Disclosure Agreement (NDA). By law, if a real adversary were to compromise a network, the findings in most industry have to be publicized. 
### Testing New Technology Implementation
Pen test can help validate technology before entering the development stage. The implementation of a penetration test of emerging technologies also saves time and resources as bugs and limitations can be quickly resolved before a system goes live.

concepts.title: History of Penetration Testing & Red Teaming

atoms.title: History of Penetration Testing & Red Teaming Heading
atoms.text: ## History of Penetration Testing & Red Teaming

atoms.title: ND350 C2 L0 A05 History Of Penetration Testing & Red Teaming

atoms.text:
## History of Penetration Testing

* **1960’s**: Pentesting formally began. The RAND Corporation came up with the idea to test the integrity of the information system. The corporation worked with the Advanced Research Projects Agency (ARPA) to publish authored a ground breaking report called The Willis Report. This report simply discussed the security problems and provided policy and technical considerations that motivated companies to conduct pen tests of their own.
* **1970’s** James P. Anderson was hired by the USAF to Pentest their time sharing systems. These are computer system shared by multiple people.  In his 1972 report he identified a series of steps that first tiger teams needed to follow to effectively test systems to see if they could be penetrated and compromised. Andersons method is still used to this day. Eight years later Anderson developed another ground breaking method for people to find out how to monitor a computer system and how to identify hacker activity.
* **1995** 
   * Security Administrator Tool for Analyzing Networks (SATAN/SANTA) became available for use. This is a Security Administrator Tool for Analyzing Networks. It also created a report that explains the issues that may arise. Now modern day tools like Nmap and Nessus have replaced it. 
   * The first bug bounty was launched by Netscape in October Bug bounty is where manufacturers and companies offer cash reward to freelance penetration testers to discover bugs in their system.

* **2001** – The Open Web Application Security Project (OWASP) an online community that produces free tools and guidelines for web application security. OWASP today is probably one of the most well known and respected site for hackers in training to go. 
* **2006** - BackTrack, a Linux distribution that focused on security was released. This would become the most utilized pen test distribution. Backtrack was later rebuilt and released by Offensive security into Kali Linux on the 13th March 2013. Kali Linux is the machine that you will be using to conduct your penetration test.

atoms.title: Introduction to Simulation/ Call from the CISO
atoms.text: ## Roles and Responsibilities

atoms.title: ND350 C2 L0 A06 Roles And Responsibility

atoms.text:
## Summary

### Offensive Team
- **Team Lead**: Plans, Schedules, and Budgets
- **Red Team**: The offensive team that end up engage with the blue team during penetration testing activities
- **Red Cell**: Simulate strategic and tactical offense
- **Red Team Operator**: Operational executor - logs info
- **Attack Group**: Attack within the required boundaries
- **Support Group**: Maintain Red Team Systems

### Defensive Team
- **Team Lead**: Plans, Schedules, and Budgets
- **Blue Team**: The defensive team that engage the red team during their pentesting activities
- **The Blue Cell**: Defenders of the Organization
- **Chief Information Security Officer (CISO)**: Responsible for Organization Security
- **Security Operations Center (SOC) Analyst**: Monitor & Defend the system
- **Information System Security Manager (ISSM)**: Manages the security Team


### Defense and Offense
- **Purple Team**: Enhance information sharing and effectiveness of the blue and red team 
- **White Cell**: referee between red and blue team
- **Engagement Control Group (ECG)**: Responsible for activities conducted in tests

atoms.title: Meet the Teams Heading
atoms.text: ## Meet the Teams

atoms.title: ND350 C2 L0 A07 Meet The Team

atoms.text:
## PJ Bank Security Team
- Mindy Castel is the **CISO**
- **Security Operation Center (SOC) Analysts**
  - Janet Pierce
  - James McLovin

## PJ Pros Team
- Paul Oyelakin is the **Team Lead**
- **Penetration Tester**
  - Jackie Wilson - specializes in testing web applications
  - Json McGuire - specializes in physical penetration and social engineering
- **You** as the intern to be part of the team!

atoms.title: Introduction To Penetration Testing & Red Team Ops
Establishing the Rules Of Engagement Heading
atoms.text: ## Establishing the Rules Of Engagement

atoms.title: ND350 C2 L0 A08 Establishing The Rules Of Engagement
Establishing the Rules Of Engagement Summary
atoms.text:
# Sections of the Rules of Engagement (RoE)

* **Introduction**: This is where you present a little background information
* **Scope of work**: Define the major milestones required to successfully complete the project
* **Risk and Limitation**: Define the limitation of testing and also establish risk likelihood. 
* **Personnel**: Identify project stakeholders (security team and red team)
* **Schedule**: Provide estimated completion dates to complete each project milestone. Does not have to be detailed. Detailed schedule will be drafted in the project plan. 
* **Testing Tools**: List tools permitted by the system owner to be used on the network. 
* **Termination of Testing**: List condition(s) that may warrant termination of pen-testing. 
* **Data Handling**: Define the expectation of the pen-test team when they come into contact with sensitive data while pen-testing. 
* **Reporting**: List the sections that must be addressed when drafting the Pen-Test report. 
* **Warranty, Limitation of liability and Indemnification**: This section is very important for the pen-test team as it limits their liability in the event their testing negatively impact network performance. 
* **Signature page**: At minimum this should be signed by the project sponsor (authorizing official from both company)
* **Test Plan**: This is where you list the actions that you know you will commit during the test. this section will have more details in a white box test. Since this is a black box test, we will not have much of a test plan until after we've gathered information (Reconnaissance)

atoms.title: Penetration Testing Kick-off Meeting Heading
atoms.text: ## Penetration Testing Kick Off Meeting

atoms.title: ND350 C2 L0 A10 Penetration Testing Kick-Off Meeting Highlights

atoms.text:
## Highlights of the Kick-Off Meeting 

- Introduced the Team members
- Determined this is a black box test
- We are approved to penetration test personnel, network, and facility
- This is an unannounced test
- Reviewed our schedule
    - 60 days to penetration test
    - 10 days after to submit report
- Reviewed testing tools to ensure they are all approved software that can be plugged into the network

atoms.title: Lab Preparations - Part 1 Heading
atoms.text: ## Environment

atoms.title: ND350 C2 L0 A11 Environment Setup
Lab Preparations - Part 1 Summary
atoms.text:
# Here is what we know so far about the network: 1. There is a publicly accessible website - mypjbank.com 1. The organization has an Intranet (DMZ) that contains the payroll server and possibly other servers (we will discover those in later lesson) 1. There is an internal subnet where employee workstation works.
MZ
Subnet (TBD)		 Connected by... Public Connected by... DMZ
Subnet (TBD)
Windows 10 Device
IP Address (TBD)		 VPN mypjbank.com VPN 1. Payroll Server
IP Address (TBD)
2. Other Devices (TBD)

# Options for accessing your lab environment:

## Option 1 (Preferred): Cloud Access

During each exercise you are provided a workspace where you can gain access to the virtual machines in your lab environment. Instructions on navigating the environment will be provided to with each exercise. 

## Option 2: Local Environment (build this out)

**THIS INSTRUCTION IS OPTIONAL AND COMPLIMENTARY WITH THE PENETRATION TESTING AND RED TEAMING NANODEGREE PROGRAM.**

This is an environment that we have designed for you to run your exercises locally. You have been provided with a cloud-lab environment, so you don’t have to worry about developing you lab locally or having a high performance physical machine with admin permissions. The local lab build out instruction is optional and only for those that wish to establish a lab environment their physical device. **We do not provide technical support for the local environment.**

**Instructions for building your lab locally can be found below.**

concepts.title: Penetration Testing Team Plan of Action Meeting

atoms.title: Penetration Testing Team Plan of Action Meeting Heading
atoms.text: ## Penetration Testing Team Plan of Action Meeting

atoms.title: Penetration Testing Kickoff Meeting
Penetration Testing Team Plan of Action Meeting Summary
atoms.text:
## Meeting Notes: 

   * Introduce the new PJ Pros employee to the team
   * It will be important for the team to follow the appropriate steps of pen testing: 
      * Recon
      * Scanning
      * Gaining access
      * Maintaining Access
      * Covering Tracks
   * Identify Cherry Tree as the common platform to collect and share Pen-test notes
      * After the project, the team will work together to draft a final report
   * Follow up meeting tomorrow to discuss Game Plan for Reconnaissance: 
   *

atoms.title: Project: Red Teaming Operations Heading
atoms.text: ## Project: Red Teaming Operations

atoms.title: Project: Red Teaming Operations Summary
atoms.text:
The CISO have been considering us for more work already! If we do well, I'm sure she will extend our contract. 

I hear they are looking to develop a website to train their employees and there is a backend server for access to internal services. You’re probably going to need to complete the following:  

* Reconnaissance
* Scanning
* Gain Access
* Exfiltrate data
* Harvest credentials
* Run SQLi

Don’t worry, I’m going to go over everything with you in this course so be sure to take good notes throughout so you’re ready

atoms.title: Lesson Recap Heading
atoms.text: ## Lesson Recap

atoms.title: ND350 C2 L0 A13 Lesson Recap
Lesson Recap Summary
atoms.text:
In this lesson we were able to: 
- Differentiate between a Pentester and a Red Team member
- Identify different roles involved in Pen Testing and Red Teaming Excercises
- Learn the History of Pen testing and Red Teaming
- Establish an effective method to retaining the information from your video lessons
- Draft a Rules of Engagement and how to present it
- Start the development of a lab environment
- Meet with others to begin collaborative efforts for a pen test project

# Further Research ## Articles: * Different Areas Of Cyber-Security to Work In * What is the Dark Web * Busted: Myth Associated with Career in Cyber Security * Breaking into Cyber Security (Video Webinar) ## Free Tutorials that may help you with basic understanding of IT: * Subnetting Part 1 * Subnetting Part 2 * NAT for Beginners

atoms.title: ND350 C2 L0 A14 Goodluck!
